unnormalised: A groundbreaking research paper published in the "Journal of Applied Mathematics" highlights a novel algorithm for solving large-scale linear systems. The algorithm, developed by Dr. Rajesh Khanna and his team at the Indian Institute of Science (IISc) Bangalore, boasts a computational complexity of O(n^2.8), a significant improvement over existing methods for matrices exceeding 1000x1000 elements. This breakthrough could have far-reaching implications for fields ranging from data science to engineering simulations.

unnormalised: The research focuses specifically on sparse matrices, a common feature in real-world applications. Traditional methods often struggle with the sheer size and computational cost associated with these matrices. Dr. Khanna's algorithm leverages a combination of advanced matrix factorization techniques and parallel processing to drastically reduce the time required for solving linear systems. The team utilized high-performance computing facilities at IISc to test the algorithm's performance on a variety of benchmark problems.

The results have been verified by independent researchers at IIT Delhi, further bolstering the credibility of the findings.
